race.name: GRAN FONDO STRADE BIANCHE
race.tagline: Ride the white roads of Tuscany. 138km through the iconic sectors. Finish in Siena's Piazza del Campo.

climate.description: March in Tuscany is a gamble. Best case: cool spring sun (10-15°C), dusty and fast. Worst case: 'epic' cold rain (2-8°C) where white dust turns to grey paste that destroys brake pads and drivetrains. Mornings near freezing—arm warmers and gilets mandatory at start.

terrain.primary: Compacted earth/clay with crushed stones—the famous 'strade bianche'
terrain.surface: ~70% paved roads, ~30-50km of gravel sectors (9-10 sectors on Gran Fondo). Not American gravel—closer to Paris-Roubaix.

prestige.explanation: The amateur version of one of cycling's most beautiful WorldTour races. Riding the strade bianche sectors that Pogacar and van der Poel attack on is bucket-list stuff. Cycling heritage is unmatched.

race_quality.explanation: Italian cycling organization at its finest. The same roads, same sectors, same finish as the pro race. Well-marked course, good feed zones, and 6,500 riders create a festival atmosphere.

experience.explanation: This is the experience. Riding through Tuscan countryside, hitting iconic sectors, finishing on Via Santa Caterina into Piazza del Campo with thousands of fans watching. The final 500m at 16% is unforgettable—'many are walking.'

community.explanation: 6,500 riders from across Europe and beyond. The shared suffering on the strade bianche creates instant camaraderie. Italian cycling culture embraces everyone from pros to tourists.

field_depth.explanation: Strong amateur field including serious European gran fondo racers. Not the same pro depth as UCI races, but very competitive at the front. Winning requires ~4-hour effort.

value.explanation: Entry cost is reasonable by European standards. The experience of riding the pro course is priceless for cycling fans. Worth the trip for the bucket-list factor alone.

expenses.explanation: Tuscan tourism pricing. Siena accommodation is available but not cheap during race week. Flights to Florence/Pisa are accessible. Budget for a proper Italian cycling trip.

logistics.explanation: RCS Sport knows how to run a race - they've got the pro Strade Bianche dialed and the gran fondo benefits from that expertise. Registration opens in September and sells out the 8,500-10,000 spots quickly, which tells you everything about demand versus supply. Starting at Fortezza Medicea and finishing in Piazza del Campo gives you proper start/finish infrastructure, not some parking lot setup.

length.explanation: At 87km for the Medio Fondo route, you're looking at a respectable morning's work without the full sufferfest. The Gran Fondo stretches to 138km if you want the complete beating, but most mortals will find 87km with 1,350m of climbing and 21km of gravel plenty challenging. It's long enough to hurt but short enough that you won't be riding in the dark.

technicality.explanation: The gravel ranges from 'compact dirt nearly as smooth as tarmac' to 'tire-deep loose gravel ready to catch careless riders.' Monte Sante Marie throws 15% gradients at you on loose stones, while Le Tolfe hits 18% in the final sector when your legs are cooked. Most riders get by fine on 30mm road tires, but you'll need to stay alert when the surface turns nasty.

elevation.explanation: The 1,350m of climbing comes in waves of punchy Tuscan hills rather than one monster ascent. You're constantly rolling up and down with frequent 8% ramps and peaks hitting 15-18% on the gravel sectors. It's not the Alps, but those short, sharp climbs on loose gravel will test your bike handling when you're already fatigued.

climate.explanation: March in Tuscany gives you proper cycling weather - 14-16°C highs with about a 24% chance of rain on any given day. You'll need layers for the morning chill but won't be suffering in summer heat when the dust gets brutal. The humidity sits around 75%, which keeps things comfortable when you're grinding through those gravel sectors.

altitude.explanation: You're rolling around the Tuscan hills at sea level to maybe 500 meters max. Unless you live in Death Valley, altitude won't even register as a factor here. The challenge comes from the terrain and distance, not thin air.

adventure.explanation: You're riding the same roads as Pogačar and the World Tour peloton, finishing in one of Italy's most iconic piazzas the day after the pros tear it up. The white gravel roads through Chianti vineyards aren't just scenic tourism - they're legitimate cycling history dating back to L'Eroica in 1997. Racing through sectors named after Fabian Cancellara while 5,000 other riders spread across Tuscany's back roads delivers the full European gran fondo experience.

biased_opinion.summary: Gran Fondo Strade Bianche is the ride every cycling fan dreams about—the same white roads, same sectors, same Piazza del Campo finish as the WorldTour race. It's not the longest or hardest gravel event, but it might be the most romantic. The Tuscan landscape, medieval villages, and Italian cycling culture create something unique. When you hit Via Santa Caterina's 16% finish and thousands cheer, you understand why cyclists make pilgrimages here.
strengths: Ride the iconic WorldTour course sectors
Finish in Piazza del Campo—cycling's most beautiful finish line
weaknesses: March weather is a gamble—can be cold and wet
Not true gravel racing—more road with gravel sectors
biased_opinion.bottom_line: If you love cycling and have never ridden the strade bianche, fix that. It's the bucket-list ride.

final_verdict.one_liner: The cycling bucket list—Tuscan white roads and Piazza del Campo finish like the WorldTour pros.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes if you love cycling culture and want the iconic experience. Yes if you can handle March weather variability. Skip if you want pure gravel racing—this is Italian road cycling with gravel sectors.
final_verdict.alternatives: Paris-Roubaix Challenge (similar spring classic feel); L'Eroica (vintage Tuscan gravel); The Traka (harder gravel, Spain)

logistics.lodging_strategy: Stay in Siena—start (Fortezza Medicea) and finish (Piazza del Campo) are in city center. Book early—race week fills up.
logistics.food: Siena has excellent dining. Pre-race pasta dinners available. Post-race celebration in Piazza del Campo.
logistics.packet_pickup: Friday/Saturday at event expo in Siena.
logistics.parking: Limited in historic center. Stay in Siena and walk/ride to start.

history.origin_story: Created as the amateur companion to the WorldTour Strade Bianche, allowing fans to ride the same iconic white roads and finish in Piazza del Campo. Has grown to 6,500+ riders.
notable_moments: Same finish as WorldTour race—Piazza del Campo
Route varies slightly but includes signature sectors
history.reputation: The cycling pilgrimage—where fans ride the roads of their heroes.

course_description.character: A mini spring classic through Tuscan countryside. The strade bianche sectors are the stars—compacted clay roads that become dusty highways when dry and grey paste when wet. Between sectors, fast paved roads with constant punchy climbs. The finish on Via Santa Caterina into Piazza del Campo is cycling theater at its finest.

suffering_zones.label: San Martino in Grania
suffering_zones.desc: 9.5km sector. Long, dragging gravel that grinds riders down. Exposed to wind.

suffering_zones.label: Monte Sante Marie
suffering_zones.desc: 11.5km—the hardest sector. Steep climbs and technical descents. 'Separates the men from the boys.'

suffering_zones.label: Le Tolfe
suffering_zones.desc: Late sector. Short but brutal kick—max 18% gradient when legs are gone.

suffering_zones.label: Via Santa Caterina
suffering_zones.desc: Final 500m paved/cobbled climb into Siena. 12% avg, 16% max. 'Many amateurs are walking' with crowds watching.

course_description.signature_challenge: Via Santa Caterina—the 16% cobbled finish into Piazza del Campo where you either crush it or walk in front of thousands.
